text: For some, it may be "doing what we've always done". But I suspect that for many more people, it's "this is what commodity tech is today, let's build interesting applications on top of it". And the more people rely on your tech as infrastructure, the harder it becomes to replace with something radially new.

elements.text: For some, it may be "doing what we've always done". But I suspect that for many more people, it's "this is what commodity tech is today, let's build interesting applications on top of it". And the more people rely on your tech as infrastructure, the harder it becomes to replace with something radially new.

text: We've invented a whole lot of stuff since 1960 not just LLM's, for example strings (GCed), hash tables, queue classes, overlapping windows, closures, etc. Many will continue to look at this stuff through a 1960s lens, whereas a few might use a 2025 lens (I hope). No radically new tech, just a different set of mental biases.
